metadata.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, New Delhi v. National Finance Ltd.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated May 1/14, 1957, of the Income Tax Appellate Tribunal, Delhi Bench, in T.A. No. 2070 of 1956-57.
Tribunal reversed order of Appellate Assistant Commissioner and held loss from sale of shares by respondent Company was capital loss.
Commissioner moved Tribunal for reference to High Court, but application barred by one day as notice reached office on July 15, 1957, but stamped July 16, 1957 due to clerk's illness.
Tribunal dismissed reference application on December 4, 1957, lacking jurisdiction to extend time.
High Court dismissed application under s.66(3) of Income-tax Act, agreeing application to Tribunal was time-barred.
Supreme Court granted special leave against Tribunal's order in the appeal.
Assessee Company, National Finance Ltd., incorporated in 1943, deals in shares and securities and as financiers.
Assessee belongs to Yodh Raj Bhalla group of companies with intimate interrelation and over 80-99% shareholdings controlled by the group.

In July 1948, Yodh Raj Bhalla arranged purchase of 26,547 shares (80% of issued capital) of Madhusudan Mills Ltd. from Bhadani Brothers at Rs. 400 per share (market Rs. 250), plus 200 shares at Rs. 252-8-0.
Funds borrowed: Rs. 14,75,000 from assessee, Rs. 5,00,000 from National Construction, Rs. 55,00,000 from assessee via Ganesh Finance.
Shares registered: 10,500 in assessee's name, 5,400 in National Construction's name, balance in nominees of Jaswant Sugar Mills.
On October 9, 1949, assessee purchased 15,547 shares from Jaswant Sugar at Rs. 400 (market Rs. 217-8-0); Jaswant sold 11,000 to National Construction at same price.
New Board of Directors appointed from same group; Bhadani Brothers' managing agency terminated; assessee appointed purchasing and selling agent.
In Oct/Nov 1948, sold 6,525 shares to Dalmia Cement at Rs. 400.
On April 7, 1949, sold 4,500 shares to National Investment Trust via Amrit Bhushan at Rs. 181, loss Rs. 8,80,000 (for 1950-51).
On June 1, 1949, sold 3,000 shares to National Investment Trust via Amrit Bhushan at Rs. 180, loss Rs. 5,86,312 (for 1951-52, year in question).
ITO and AAC held loss as capital loss; Tribunal held trading loss.
Loss claimed as stock-in-trade loss for year May 1, 1949 to April 30, 1950 (assessment 1951-52).

legal_issues.text: Whether the appeal is competent in view of Chandi Prasad Chokhani, given special circumstances of delay in reference application.
Whether the loss arising from sale of 3,000 shares of Madhusudan Mills Ltd. is a capital loss or trading loss.

petitioner_arguments.text: Special circumstances exist similar to Baldev Singh case: notice received July 15 but stamped July 16 due to clerk's illness, leading to one-day delay; no negligence by Commissioner.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Baldev Singh v. Commissioner of Income tax

petitioner_arguments.text: Shares purchased at double market price to acquire controlling interest and agencies, not as stock-in-trade; loss is capital.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Ramnarain Sons Ltd. v. CIT; Oriental Investment Co. Ltd. v. CIT

respondent_arguments.text: Appeal incompetent per Chandi Prasad Chokhani; no exceptional circumstances.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Chandi Prasad Chokhani v. State of Bihar

respondent_arguments.text: Each company separate entity per Salomon v. Salomon; assessee's intention was trading, not capital acquisition.

court_reasoning.text: Overrules preliminary objection: special circumstances like Baldev Singh (clerk's illness, wrong date stamp) justify direct appeal; no bypassing High Court as High Court dealt only with limitation.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Default not due to negligence of Commissioner; comes within rule of Baldev Singh.

court_reasoning.text: Whether loss trading or capital is mixed question of fact and law; depends on intention at acquisition.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Approach in light of intention, considering legal requirements of trade.

court_reasoning.text: Shares bought at double market price by group to oust Bhadani Brothers, secure agencies for assessee; not prudent business unless for enduring benefit.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Price excess indicates acquisition beyond shares, for controlling interest and agencies.

court_reasoning.text: Group companies interlinked, same control; Jaswant interposed as device; benefits conferred on assessee from day one; Salomon not applicable to pierce for intention.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Transaction on capital side; shares not stock-in-trade, sold within group to offset profits.

holdings.text: Appeal competent due to special circumstances.
Loss on sale of shares is capital loss, not trading loss.

precedents_cited.case_name: Chandi Prasad Chokhani v. State of Bihar
precedents_cited.relevance: No direct appeal from Tribunal bypassing High Court except exceptional circumstances.

precedents_cited.case_name: Baldev Singh v. Commissioner of Income tax
precedents_cited.relevance: Special circumstances (postal delay) justified special leave.

precedents_cited.case_name: Indian Aluminium Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax
Kanhaiyalal Lohia v. Commissioner of Income-tax
Dhakeswari Cotton Mills Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents_cited.relevance: Breach of natural justice justified special leave.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Ramnarain Sons Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Shares bought above market for managing agency are capital.

precedents_cited.case_name: Kishan Prasad & Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents_cited.relevance: No intention to resell shares bought for managing agency.

precedents_cited.case_name: Oriental Investment Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents_cited.relevance: Object of company formation not decisive; consider circumstances.

precedents_cited.case_name: Rajputana Textiles v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents_cited.relevance: Separate payments for agency and shares made it trading.
Companies separate, but here for ascertaining intention in loss nature.

statutes_cited.name: Income-tax Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Application to High Court when Tribunal refuses reference.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Limitation Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Tribunal has no jurisdiction to extend time unlike under Limitation Act.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court overruled preliminary objection, held appeal competent, and reversed Tribunal to hold the loss from sale of shares as capital loss, not trading loss.
outcome.relief_granted: Appeal allowed in favour of Commissioner.

key_quotes.text: Whether a particular loss is a trading loss or a loss on the capital side undoubtedly depends upon the facts of each case. But it has been held, over and over again, that the question is not one of pure fact, and that a mixed question of fact and law is always involved.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: In our opinion, this transaction must be regarded as one on the capital side. Shares were never treated as part of the stock-in-trade.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: The price per share was considerably in excess of the prevailing market rate. The only reason for entering into the transaction... was the acquisition of the managing agency.
key_quotes.speaker: court
